rows.description: The Amazon Bedrock model identifier to use for AI processing. See [AWS Documentation](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/bedrock/latest/userguide/models-supported.html) for supported models. Available models include `anthropic.claude-v2`, `amazon.titan-text-express-v1`, and `ai21.j2-ultra-v1`.
The AWS region where the Bedrock service is located. Must be a region that supports **Amazon Bedrock**. Supported regions include `us-east-1`, `us-west-2`, `eu-west-1`, and `ap-southeast-1`.
AWS access key ID for authentication. Required for `AWS IAM` authentication. **Security Note:** Never expose access keys in client-side code or commit them to version control.

AWS secret access key for authentication. **Keep this secure** and never expose in client-side code. Consider using [IAM roles](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/id_roles.html) instead of access keys when possible.
AWS session token. Required when using **temporary credentials** or `STS` authentication. Only needed for temporary credentials or when assuming roles.
Maximum number of tokens to generate in the response. Higher values allow longer responses but increase cost. Typical range is `100` to `4000` depending on the model.
Controls randomness in the model's output. Range: `0.0` to `1.0`. Lower values (`0.1-0.3`) are more deterministic, higher values (`0.7-0.9`) are more creative. Use `0.7` as a good starting point.
Nucleus sampling parameter for controlling diversity. Range: `0.0` to `1.0`. Use **either** `temperature` or `top_p`, not both. Lower values (`0.1-0.5`) focus on more likely tokens.
